{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox venue | name = J.L. Johnson Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = 81st Street and Lewis Avenue, [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]], [[Oklahoma|OK]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|36.049894|-95.948662|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = 1977–1978 | opened = March 6, 1978 | renovated = 2009 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Oral Roberts University]] | operator = Oral Roberts University | surface = Natural [[grass]] | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,418 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 330 ft. ([[Left field|LF]]), 375 ft. (LCF), 400 ft. ([[Baseball field#outfield|CF]]), 375 ft. (RCF), 330 ft. ([[Right field|RF]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[Oral Roberts Golden Eagles baseball]] ([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[The Summit League|The Summit]]) (1978–present) }}
'''J.L. Johnson Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], United States. It is home to the [[Oral Roberts Golden Eagles baseball]] team of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[The Summit League]]. Dedicated on June 17, 1977, the stadium was opened on March 6, 1978, for a game against [[Southeastern Oklahoma State University]]. Oral Roberts won the game 7–6. The venue's seated capacity is 2,418 spectators.<ref name=facil>{{cite web|title=J.L. Johnson Stadium|url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=3746967|work=ORU Golden Eagles|accessdate=August 15, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60xqpZqH1?url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=3746967#|archivedate=August 15, 2011|date=June 5, 2009|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Features == Johnson Stadium's most notable feature is its [[cantilever]]ed roof, similar to that of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]'s [[Estadio Hiram Bithorn]] and [[Lynn, Massachusetts]]'s [[Fraser Field]].<ref name=db>{{cite web|last=Pastore |first=Eric and Wendy |title=J.L. Johnson Stadium |url=http://www.digitalballparks.com/NCAA/ORU.html |work=Digital Ballparks |accessdate=August 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60xr5TzBh?url=http://www.digitalballparks.com/NCAA/ORU.html |archivedate=August 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> White, zig-zag patterned paneling forms a roof and facade which cover most of the venue's seating. This seating is elevated, with the first row of seats starting at the dugout roofs' height.<ref name=charlie>{{cite web|last=O'Reilly |first=Charles |title=Mr. Roberts Built It |url=http://mysite.verizon.net/charliesballparks/stadiums/oralrob.htm |work=Charlie's Ballparks |accessdate=August 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60xrZk0T7?url=http://mysite.verizon.net/charliesballparks/stadiums/oralrob.htm |archivedate=August 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
A thirty-foot [[batter's eye]] stands in center field, with an electronic scoreboard in right center. The stadium's outfield walls were replaced during 2009 renovations.<ref name="facil" />
The venue also features stadium lighting,<ref name="charlie" /> [[Dugout (baseball)|dugouts]], a mesh backstop,<ref name="db" /> a [[press box]], locker rooms, and practice facilities.<ref name=ORUphotos>{{cite web|title=J.L. Johnson Stadium Photo Gallery|url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=1104472|work=ORU Golden Eagles|accessdate=August 15, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60xrpxgPO?url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=1104472#|archivedate=August 15, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2006, the Golden Eagle Sports Complex, which includes workout space, an indoor practice facility, baseball offices, and the Grand Slam Room (from which program boosters can watch games), was added. The complex cost [[USD|$]]1.6 million on the project.<ref name=GESC>{{cite web|title=Golden Eagle Sports Complex|url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=3747072|work=ORU Golden Eagles|accessdate=August 15, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60xtU9urb?url=http://www.orugoldeneagles.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17000&ATCLID=3747072#|archivedate=August 15, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Tournaments hosted == J.L. Johnson has hosted many postseason tournaments, the dates of which are listed below.<ref name="facil" /><ref name=2010SLT>{{cite web|title=2010 Summit League Baseball Championship|url=http://www.thesummitleague.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=3900&ATCLID=204938602|work=The Summit League|accessdate=August 15, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606223024/http://www.thesummitleague.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=3900&ATCLID=204938602|dead-url=yes|archivedate=June 6, 2010}}</ref>
*[[NCAA]] Midwest [[Oral Roberts Golden Eagles|Regional]]: 1978, 1980, 1981 *[[Midwestern Collegiate Conference]] Tournament: 1981, 1983, 1985 *[[Mid-Continent Conference]] Tournament: 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2005, 2006 *[[Summit League]] Tournament: 2008, 2009, 2010, 2012<ref name=12tourney>{{cite web|title=2012 Summit League Baseball Championship|url=http://www.thesummitleague.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=3900&ATCLID=205240778|work=The Summit League|accessdate=February 12, 2012}}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

{{Infobox stadium | fullname = JPS Field at Malone Stadium | nickname = The Hawk | image = File:ULM Warhawks Stadium, Monroe, LA IMG 2779.JPG | image_size = 300px | location = 514 Warhawk Way
[[Monroe, Louisiana]] 71203 | coordinates = {{coord|32|31|51|N|92|3|57|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1977 | opened = September 16, 1978 | renovated = 2008, 2014 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] | operator = [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = $2.5 million | architect = [[Hugh G. Parker, Jr.]] Architects (renovations) | former_names = | seating_capacity = 27,617 (2014–present) | record_attendance = 31,175
(September 21, 2012 vs. [[2012 Baylor Bears football team|Baylor]]) | tenants = [[Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks football]] (1978–present) |}} [[File:Malone Stadium panorama.jpg|right|thumb|300px|JPS Field at Malone Stadium]] '''JPS Field at Malone Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Monroe, Louisiana]], United States, on the campus of the [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]]. It is primarily used for football and is the home field of the [[Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks football|ULM Warhawks]]. The stadium, named for former coach [[James L. Malone]], opened in 1978 and has a seating capacity of 27,617 people. The field is named JPS Field, for a local company, JPS Aviation/JPS Equipment Rental. The field was named after the company after they agreed to fund installation of a new [[FieldTurf]] playing surface in 2014. ==History== Because Northeast Louisiana University's previous stadium could hold just over 8,000 spectators, the late Mayor [[W. L. "Jack" Howard]] pushed for construction of a new football stadium.{{cite web|url=http://si.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1091504/9/index.htm|title=John Underwood, "New Boys On The Block: From the day he's hired, a college football coach has two things in common with his predecessor—a belief he can do the job, a good chance he won't. Meet four fresh optimists," September 6, 1976|publisher=si.com|accessdate=July 6, 2013}} Malone Stadium, named after the winningest coach in school history [[James L. Malone]], opened on September 16, 1978, with a capacity of 20,000, with the then-Northeast Louisiana Indians beat Arkansas State, 21–13. It is located across Bayou Desiard from the main campus, the center of the school's athletic facilities. The field runs roughly north-northeast, with an imbalanced grandstand, the west stands being the larger stands. The lower west level is a solid enclosed structure, with the ULM Athletic Training Center enclosed, and the upper level extends much higher, with the press box and luxury boxes located on top. The east side is also decked, with a short first deck wrapping around almost from goalpost to goalpost and another short steel-supported upper deck running the length of the field. ===Renovations=== Both sides of seating were extended into each [[end zone]] in 1983, increasing the capacity to 23,277. The press box was enlarged in 1991, and capacity decreased to 22,077. In 1993, 8,350 seats were added to the stadium, increasing capacity to its current figure of 30,427. [[File:Malone scoreboard.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Scoreboard in 2012]] In 2007, ULM excavated the natural grass from Malone Stadium to install ProPlay artificial turf.{{cite web|title=Work begins on field at Malone Stadium |date=April 30, 2007 |url=http://www.ulmwarhawks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?temp_site=NO&DB_OEM_ID=19000&ATCLID=1318397&SPID=10968&SPSID=90583}} Retrieved on October 12, 2009. In 2011, the university installed a new scoreboard with a high definition video display measuring 23 feet high by 48 feet wide (1,104 square feet) and flanked by two low definition video panels for advertisements measuring 16 feet high by 14 feet wide.[http://www.daktronics.com/Company/NewsReleases/Pages/UniversityofLouisianaMonroe.aspx University of Louisiana at Monroe to Upgrade with Daktronics LED Technology] Also, a new sound system was installed in the upper corners of the scoreboard. A record crowd of 31,175 was reached on September 21, 2012 against the [[2012 Baylor Bears football team|Baylor Bears]] at the 2012 home opener. In 2014, JPS Aviation/JPS Equipment Rental paid $450,000 to replace the artificial turf with new [[FieldTurf]] and for the field to be named JPS Field at Malone Stadium for the next eight seasons.http://www.ulmwarhawks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=209392972 A new field house facility was completed in August 2016 at a cost of $4.1 million. The {{convert|11750|sqft|adj=on}} building is located in the north end zone, attached to the west grandstand. It features a hall of fame area, locker room, coaches’ offices, and patios overlooking the field.{{cite news |title=ULM unveils much-anticipated football facility |url=http://www.thenewsstar.com/story/sports/college/ulm/2016/08/02/ulm-unveils-much-anticipated-football-facility/87963344/ |newspaper=The News-Star |author=Hunsucker, Adam |date=August 2, 2016 |accessdate=May 9, 2017}} ==Top 10 Largest Crowds== The largest crowd to see a Warhawk football game in Malone Stadium was 31,175 on September 21, 2012, when the Warhawks hosted Baylor University. {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks|color=white}};"|Rank !! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks|color=white}};"|Date !! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks|color=white}};"|Attendance !! {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} '''James Farry''' (1 July 1954 – 10 November 2010)<ref name=scotobit>{{cite news|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-jim-farry-football-administrator-1-833291|title=Obituary: Jim Farry, football administrator|date=12 November 2010|accessdate=13 November 2010|work=[[The Scotsman]]|location=Edinburgh}}</ref> served as chief executive of the [[Scottish Football Association]] from 1990 to 1999. Farry was forced to leave that post due to a dispute with [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] over the registration of player [[Jorge Cadete]].
==Early life== Farry attended school in [[East Kilbride]], before working as a landscape gardener, milkman and window cleaner.<ref name="death"/> He first joined the [[Scottish Football Association]] (SFA) in 1972 as an administration assistant.<ref name = "death"/> In the late 1970s he was appointed secretary of the [[Scottish Football League]], a position he held for over 10 years.<ref name="death"/> Farry earned a reputation as an efficient administrator during his stint as league secretary. When the same position at the SFA became vacant in 1990, he was appointed as the successor to the departing Ernie Walker.<ref name="death"/><ref name="bbc">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/292088.stm|title=Farry sacked by SFA |publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=8 March 2009|accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref>
==SFA chief executive== While chief executive, Farry oversaw the project to renovate Scotland's national football stadium [[Hampden Park]].<ref name="hampden">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/football/scotland/2010/11/11/former-sfa-chief-executive-jim-farry-dies-aged-55-86908-22708214|title=Former SFA chief executive Jim Farry dies aged 55|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=11 November 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref> The 'new Hampden' as it was termed, drew both support and criticism, with opinion divided over the need for a dedicated national stadium within Scotland. As the stadium is used at club level by [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]], an amateur team currently playing in the lower divisions and possessing limited support, some footballing figures had argued that an existing stadium could have served as a home for the Scottish national team indefinitely. Alternatively, supporters of the stadium have pointed to the awarding of [[UEFA Elite stadium|UEFA elite status]] and the hosting of a number of high-profile matches, most notably the [[2002 UEFA Champions League Final]] and the [[2007 UEFA Cup Final]], as proof of the renovation's success.
===Princess of Wales Controversy=== In 1997, Farry attracted criticism from some parts of the media in the aftermath of the death of [[Diana Princess of Wales]], after he publicly rejected calls to cancel a scheduled international match between [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] and [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] on the day of the Princess's funeral.<ref name="diana">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/politics97/diana/soccer.html|title=Calls For Farry to Quit Over Saturday Soccer Match |publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> He later revealed that he had been advised by Buckingham Palace to let the game go ahead; however after a hostile reaction from the media and certain sections of society, the match was eventually rescheduled.<ref name = "diana"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/top-football-stories/queen-told-us-to-play-game-reveals-farry-1-1099500 |title=Queen told us to play game, reveals Farry |date=8 October 2005 |accessdate=19 March 2012 |work=[[The Scotsman]]|location=Edinburgh}}</ref> [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of Parliament (UK)|MP]] [[Jimmy Hood]] and the ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' newspaper called on Farry to resign, while Rangers players [[Ally McCoist]], [[Andy Goram]] and [[Gordon Durie]] had refused to play in the match if it had been played on the day of the funeral.<ref name="diana"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-the-great-flaw-of-scotland-1237918.html|last=Gordon|first=Phil|title=The great flaw of Scotland|date=7 September 1997|accessdate=4 November 2010|location=London|work=The Independent}}</ref>
===Jorge Cadete=== In 1999, an independent commission was called to examine allegations made by the then [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] managing director and majority shareholder [[Fergus McCann]] concerning the registration of [[Portugal|Portuguese]] player [[Jorge Cadete]] in 1996.<ref name="bbc"/> A player must be registered with the [[Scottish Football Association|SFA]] before he is permitted to play in matches in Scotland. A delay in the registration had forced Cadete to miss a [[Scottish Cup]] semi-final against their [[Old Firm]] rivals [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]], which Celtic lost 2–1.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name = "suspended">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/288283.stm |title=SFA boss suspended |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=1 March 1999 |accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> McCann claimed that the delay was deliberate and the commission ruled in his favour.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name = "suspended"/> On 8 March 1999, Farry was sacked for gross misconduct.<ref name="bbc"/>
==Life after football== As of 2009, Farry was employed as a business development manager by medium-sized construction and refurbishment firm AKP Scotland, based in [[East Kilbride]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/football/-Farry39s-fall-from-grace.5004457.jp|work=[[Scotland On Sunday]]|date=22 February 2009|accessdate=4 November 2010|title=Farry's fall from grace}}</ref> He was also a patron of [[Cambuslang RFC|Cambuslang Rugby Club]].<ref name=scotobit/>
Following a massive heart attack in his home in [[Cambuslang]], Farry died on 10 November 2010 in [[Hairmyres Hospital]], East Kilbride, shortly afterwards. He was survived by his wife and two children.<ref name=scotobit/><ref name="death">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/former-sfa-chief-jim-farry-dies-at-56-1.1067426|work=[[The Herald (Scotland)|The Herald]]|last=Williams|first= Martin|title=Former SFA chief Jim Farry dies at 56|date=11 November 2010|accessdate=11 November 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Scottish Football Association}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Farry, Jim}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:People from East Kilbride]] [[Category:Chief executives of the Scottish Football Association]] [[Category:Association football controversies]] [[Category:Cambuslang]] [[Category:Sportspeople from South Lanarkshire]]

{{Horseraces infobox |class = Discontinued stakes |horse race = |image = |caption = |location = [[Latonia Race Track]]
[[Latonia, Covington|Latonia, Kentucky]] |inaugurated = 1883 |race type = [[Thoroughbred]] - [[Flat racing]] |website = |distance = 1¼ miles (10 furlongs) |track = Dirt, left-handed |qualification = Three-years-old |weight = |purse = [[United States dollar|$12,800]] |bonuses = }} The '''Latonia Derby''' was an American [[Thoroughbred horse race]] run annually from 1883 through 1937 at [[Latonia Race Track]] in [[Latonia, Covington|Latonia, Kentucky]].[https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1930s/drf1935052901/drf1935052901_31_8 ''Daily Racing Form'', 1935-05-29 "Almost as Old as the Kentucky Derby"]Open to three-year-old horses, for its first 52 years the Latonia Derby was contested at a mile and a half then in 1935 the distance was shortened to a mile and a quarter. It was run as the Hindoo Stakes from inception in 1883 to 1886 in honor of the Kentucky-bred [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]] horse, [[Hindoo (horse)|Hindoo]].https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1910s/drf1912051701/drf1912051701_2_4 "Latonia Derby Rich In Promise" - ''Daily Racing Form'', 1912-05-17 The race usually attracted the [[Kentucky Derby]] winner; it became so popular that in 1912 a [[film|motion picture]] was made by [[Universal Studios|Independent Motion Picture Co.]] entitled ''Winning the Latonia Derby'', featuring [[silent film]] star [[King Baggot]]. The inaugural 1883 Latonia Derby was won by Kentucky Derby winner [[Leonatus]]. Future Derby winners [[Kingman (American horse)|Kingman]] (1891), [[Halma (horse)|Halma]] (1895), [[Ben Brush]] (1896), [[Lieut. Gibson]] (1900), [[Elwood (horse)|Elwood]] (1904) and [[Sir Huon]] (1906) also won the race; the 1918 edition was won by [[Harry Payne Whitney|Harry Payne Whitney's]] [[Belmont Stakes]]-winning colt, [[Johren]]. In 1936, [[Rushaway]] won the [[Illinois Derby]] during the afternoon, then was shipped {{convert|300|mi|km}} overnight to win the Latonia Derby the following afternoon.[https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1930s/drf1936052501/drf1936052501_1_2 ''Daily Racing Form'', 1936-05-25, "A. G. Tarn's "Iron Horse" Accomplishes Unparalleled Turf Feat"] ==Records== '''Speed record:''' * 1¼ miles (1935-1937) : 2:02 3/5 - [[Rushaway]] (1936)[https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1920s/drf1927062701/drf1927062701_1_3 ''Daily Racing Form'', 1927-06-27 article titled "Handy Mandy's Latonia Derby: H. P. Headleys Gallant Filly Scores Most Notable Victory"] * 1½ miles (1883-1934) : 2:28 3/5 - [[Handy Mandy]] (1927) '''Most wins by a [[jockey]]:''' * 5 - [[Isaac Burns Murphy|Isaac Murphy]] (1883, 1885, 1886, 1887, 1891)[https://drf.uky.edu/catalog/1930s/drf1931061201/drf1931061201_17_6 ''Daily Racing Form'', 1931-06-12, "I. {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Lincoln Park Grounds | nickname = Union Grounds
The Grand Duchess | image = | location = Hopkins & McLean Ave. [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] | broke_ground = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Cincinnati Red Stockings]] | seating_capacity = 4,000 | dimensions = }} The '''Lincoln Park Grounds''', commonly known as '''Union Grounds''', were a former [[baseball]] park located in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]. The Grounds were built for the Union Cricket Club in 1856; they "were used for cricket and baseball in the summer and were flooded for skating in the winter."''The Cincinnati Historical Society Bulletin'', v. 27 (1969), p. 30. In 1865 [[Harry Wright]] became the professional of the Cincinnati Cricket Club, which also used the grounds, and the next year Aaron Champion, president of the new [[Cincinnati Red Stockings|Cincinnati Base Ball Club]], "approached Wright to propose a limited use of the grounds if the CBBC and Live Oaks club would put in $2000 each to revamp the Lincoln Park Grounds."Christopher Devine, ''Harry Wright'' (McFarland, 2003: {{ISBN|0-7864-1561-4}}), p. 30.
A year later the [Red Stockings] leased the grounds of the Union Cricket Club for its home tilts. Most club members referred to the field as the Union Grounds, although it also was known as the Union Cricket Club Grounds and the Lincoln Park Grounds, given the fact that the eight-acre, fenced grounds were located in a small park behind Lincoln Park in Cincinnati, near the [[Union Terminal (Cincinnati)|Union Terminal]]. It was a twenty-minute ride by streetcar to the Union Grounds from the heart of downtown Cincinnati. Aaron Champion ordered that approximately $10,000 worth of improvements be made to the home grounds for the 1867 season, including grading and sodding of the field and building of a new clubhouse and stands.Stephen D. Guschov, ''The Red Stockings of Cincinnati'' (McFarland, 1998: {{ISBN|0-7864-0467-1}}), p. 10.
The Union Grounds were used until 1875; the next year a new [[Cincinnati Reds (1876-1880)|Cincinnati Red Stockings]] club moved to the [[Avenue Grounds]] two miles to the north.[http://www.mlb.com/cin/history/ballparks.jsp Reds Ballparks]. ==References== {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Cincinnati Red Stockings]] | years = 1867 – 1870 | before = [[Live Oaks Base Ball Grounds]] | after = - }} {{end}} {{Cincinnati Reds}} {{coord|39|06|32.23|N|84|31|56.97|W|region:US_type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cincinnati]] [[Category:Baseball in Cincinnati]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1856]] [[Category:Defunct cricket grounds]] {{Ohio-baseball-venue-stub}} {{Cincinnati-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Lioli FC | image = [[File:Lioli FC (logo).png|200px]] | fullname = Lioli Football Club | nickname = Tse Nala | founded = 1934 | ground = [[Lioli Ground]]
[[Teyateyaneng]], [[Lesotho]] | stadium = Lioli Football Stadium | capacity = 3,000 (Standing) | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Lesotho Premier League]] | season = 2017–18 | current = 2018-19 | position = 2nd| }} '''Lioli Football Club''' is a team in the [[Lesotho]] Premier League. The team is based in [[Teyateyaneng]]. The club has won five league championships, in 1985, 2009, 2013, 2015, and 2016. The team's kit is manufactured by [[Basutoland Ink]].{{cite web|last1=Sunday Express|url=http://sundayexpress.co.ls/lioli-seal-kit-deal-with-basutoland-ink/|accessdate=22 December 2014|title=Sunday Express}} [[File:lioli Style.JPG|thumb]] [[File:Lioli skill.jpg|thumb]] ==Achievements== *'''[[Lesotho Premier League]]: 5''' ::1985, 2009, 2013, 2015, 2016 *'''[[Lesotho Independence Cup|Lesotho Cup]]: 5''' ::1984, 2007, 2010, 2014, 2016 *'''[[Lesotho Premier League's Top Goalscorer]]: ::2012–13: Ts'epo Seturumane with 16 goals. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722150119/http://www.liolifc.co.ls/ Official website] {{Lesotho Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Lesotho]] {{Lesotho-footyclub-stub}}

page.title: List of Premier League highest scoring games

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} This is a summary of the highest scoring games and biggest winning margins in the [[Premier League]] since its establishment in the [[1992–93 FA Premier League|1992–93]] season. The record for the biggest win is [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]'s [[Manchester United F.C. 9–0 Ipswich Town F.C.|9–0 victory]] against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] at [[Old Trafford]] on 4th March 1995. [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] are the only other club to have scored nine goals in a Premier League game - in their 9–1 victory over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at [[White Hart Lane]] on 22 November 2009. This game also boasts the record number of goals scored by both teams in one half of Premier League football (nine), and by one team in one half of Premier League football (eight, by Tottenham). Manchester United also hold the record for the biggest winning margin away from home with an [[Nottingham Forest F.C. 1–8 Manchester United F.C.|8–1 victory]] over Nottingham Forest at the City Ground in Nottingham on 6 February 1999. The highest scoring game is Portsmouth's [[Portsmouth F.C. 7–4 Reading F.C.|7–4 win]] against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] at [[Fratton Park]] on 29 September 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/portsmth-vs-reading/88967|title=Portsmouth 7-4 Reading|date=29 September 2007|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|accessdate=14 May 2018}} ==Highest scoring games== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! page.title: List of managers and coaches who have qualified for the UEFA Pro Licence

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2008}} {{inc-sport}}
The following managers and coaches have passed the qualifications required in order to hold a [[UEFA Pro Licence]], the highest-level managerial qualification in [[association football]] in Europe.
== England ==
{{div col|colwidth=22em}}
===Qualified in 2002===
*[[Noel Blake]] *[[Terry Burton]] *[[Tony Dorigo]] *[[Steve Cotterill]] *[[Mervyn Day]] *[[Dario Gradi]] *[[Stewart Houston]] *[[Martin Hunter (football coach)|Martin Hunter]] *[[Chris Hughton]] *[[Sammy Lee (footballer)|Sammy Lee]]<ref name=whatis/> *[[Lawrie Sanchez]]<ref name=whatis/> *[[Alan Smith (manager)|Alan Smith]] *[[Martin Rennie]]
===Qualified in 2003===
*[[Stuart Baxter]] *[[Phil Brown (footballer born 1959)|Phil Brown]] *[[Willie Donachie]] *[[Joe Joyce]] *[[Derek Fazackerley]] *[[Stuart Gray (footballer, born 1960)|Stuart Gray]] *[[John McDermott (football coach)|John McDermott]]{{cn|date=November 2017}} *[[Mark McGhee]] *[[Alan Pardew]] *[[Stuart Pearce]]<ref name=whatis/> *[[Nigel Pearson]] *[[David Platt (footballer)|David Platt]] *[[Hope Powell]] - the first [[female]] to qualify *[[Nigel Spackman]] *[[Dave Watson]] *[[Peter Withe]] *[[Nigel Worthington]]

{{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox venue | name = Meadowbank Stadium | image = [[File:Meadowbank Stadium stand.jpg|250px]] | image_caption = Meadowbank Stadium | pushpin_map = Scotland Edinburgh | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Edinburgh | pushpin_label_position = left | coordinates = {{coord|55|57|25|N|3|9|31|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | location =[[Meadowbank, Edinburgh]], Scotland | type = Outdoor [[Sport]]s / [[Concert]] [[Stadium]] | genre = | broke_ground = | built = 1967–1970 | opened = 1970 | renovated = 1994, 1999, 2017– | expanded = | owner = | former_names = New Meadowbank, Old Meadowbank | tenants = [[Livingston F.C.|Meadowbank Thistle F.C.]] (1974–1995)
[[Edinburgh City F.C.]] (1996–2017)
[[Edinburgh Rugby]] (2002–2004)
[[Leith Athletic F.C.]] (3G pitch, 2013–2017) | seating_type = Individual backed seats in stand, bench seats all other areas | seating_capacity = {{SPFL-stadiums|edinburghcity}} | website = [https://www.edinburghleisure.co.uk/venues/meadowbank-sports-centre Edinburgh Leisure] }} '''Meadowbank Stadium''' (officially '''Meadowbank Sports Centre''') is a multi-purpose sports facility located in the [[Meadowbank, Edinburgh|Meadowbank]] area of [[Edinburgh]], Scotland. Built on the site of the earlier [[New Meadowbank]] and [[Old Meadowbank]] sports venues, it was originally built to host the [[1970 Commonwealth Games]]. It also hosted the Games in [[1986 Commonwealth Games|1986]], becoming the first venue to host the Games twice. The stadium has also regularly hosted [[Association football|football]]. It was the home ground of [[Scottish Football League]] team [[Livingston F.C.|Meadowbank Thistle]] between 1974 and 1995. From 1996, it hosted senior non-league football as the home ground of [[Edinburgh City F.C.|Edinburgh City]]. League football returned to Meadowbank in 2016 following City's promotion to the [[Scottish Professional Football League]]. The Meadowbank complex also hosts [[Leith Athletic F.C.|Leith Athletic]], who have played on the '''Meadowbank 3G''' artificial pitch adjacent to the main stadium since 2013. As of 2017, the stadium is being redeveloped. Meadowbank Stadium was also used for [[rugby union]] as the home venue of [[Edinburgh Rugby]] between 2002 and 2004. ==Layout== Before the stadium was closed for redevelopment work in 2017, the capacity of the stadium was 5,000.{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/clubs/edinburgh-city/ |title=Edinburgh City Football Club |work= |publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |date= |accessdate=18 May 2016}} The stadium consisted of a main grandstand, with uncovered benches around the rest of the running track. It was built on the site of [[New Meadowbank]] stadium, while the indoor sports complex and adjacent pitches to the east were built on the site of [[Old Meadowbank]] stadium. The stadium itself contains an eight lane, 400 metre running track, with a grass pitch within this. There is also a [[velodrome]] adjacent to the site. Underneath the stand is a covered 100 metre, eight-lane track. The stadium contains indoor facilities, including squash and basketball courts. These are also used for antiques fairs, martial arts competitions, conferences, and church meetings. Other outdoor facilities include field hockey pitches. ==Uses== [[File:Meadowbank Stadium panorama.jpg|thumb|left|800px]]{{Clear}} ===Commonwealth Games=== Meadowbank Stadium was built for the [[1970 Commonwealth Games]], at a cost of £2.8 million. It was opened by [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent]] on 2 May 1970.{{harvnb|Inglis|1987|p=341}} The 1970 Games was one of the most successful in the history of the event.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/more-sport/athletics/glasgow-makes-final-call-for-2014-games-1-746056 |title=Glasgow makes final call for 2014 games |work=The Scotsman |publisher=Johnston Publishing |date=9 May 2007 |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-21674542 |title=The good and bad of Commonwealth Games |first=Cameron |last=Buttle |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=7 March 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} The [[1986 Commonwealth Games]] were also held at Meadowbank, which became the first venue to host the Commonwealth Games twice. The 1986 Games suffered a financial deficit and were widely boycotted due to the support of the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British Government]] for the [[apartheid]] regime in [[South Africa]]. The stadium once had its own [[Meadowbank Stadium railway station|railway station]] which was built for the 1986 Commonwealth Games. ===Football=== [[Livingston F.C.|Meadowbank Thistle]] played at the stadium from 1974 until the club relocated to the [[new town]] of [[Livingston, Scotland|Livingston]] in 1995.{{harvnb|Inglis|1996|p=455}} Meadowbank is often cited as one of the worst stadiums used in the [[Scottish Football League]] due to the lack of atmosphere in the ground. This was caused by the stadium having a capacity of {{SPFL-stadiums|edinburghcity}}, but Meadowbank typically attracted crowds of less than 1,000. Most fans were located on one side of the ground, while the running track created a great distance between the fans and the pitch. Meadowbank Thistle announced their intention to leave the stadium and relocate to Livingston in 1995, when their lease expired. Their last game as Meadowbank Thistle was played in May 1995, although they continued to play at Meadowbank Stadium as Livingston until their new [[Almondvale Stadium]] was ready in November 1995. [[Edinburgh City F.C.|Edinburgh City]] moved into the stadium after Meadowbank left and they have since been joined by [[Leith Athletic F.C.|Leith Athletic]] (from the East of Scotland League). [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] have also played some of their [[reserve team]] matches at Meadowbank.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/latest/mcmanus-impresses-as-smith-earns-hibs-reserves-a-draw-1-1337952 |title=McManus impresses as Smith earns Hibs reserves a draw |work=Edinburgh Evening News |publisher=Johnston Publishing |date=14 February 2007 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} ===Music=== [[File:Meadowbank Stadium - Radiohead.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Meadowbank Stadium prior to performance by [[Radiohead]] at the 2006 [[The Edge Festival|T on the Fringe]], taken from the main seating area]] Meadowbank was used as a 25,000 capacity concert venue during T on the Fringe, an annual music festival. [[Muse (band)|Muse]], [[My Chemical Romance]], [[Snow Patrol]], [[Radiohead]], [[Pixies]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Nine Inch Nails]], [[Kaiser Chiefs]] and [[Razorlight]] all played the venue between 2005 and 2007. In 2008, T on the Fringe was renamed [[The Edge Festival]] and the stadium was no longer used as one of the main venues. In 1989, [[Simple Minds]] played Meadowbank on their [[Street Fighting Years]] Tour after switching from [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield]]. The switch was due to the band's passionate anti-[[apartheid]] beliefs clashing with the [[Scottish Rugby Union]]'s decision to play in South Africa at the time. ===Basketball=== Meadowbank stadium has basketball facilities in three of its large halls, but they are only rarely available to the public. Edinburgh Rocks basketball team used one of the large halls until they moved to the [[Braehead Arena]], and were renamed [[Scottish Rocks]]. ===Track cycling=== [[File:Meadowbank Stadium - geograph.org.uk - 418221.jpg|thumb|400px|Meadowbank Stadium]] Meadowbank velodrome is home to the East of Scotland regional track cycling academy. The 250 metre track made of African timber was built by Schuermann Architects of Germany for the [[1986 Commonwealth Games]].{{cite web| url=http://www.bikecult.com/bikecultbook/sports_velodromes.html| publisher=Bike Cult| title=Bicycle Tracks & Velodromes| date=25 July 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordcityrc.fsnet.co.uk/training/calshot.htm |title=A trip to the Calshot track |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050325085825/http://www.oxfordcityrc.fsnet.co.uk/training/calshot.htm |archivedate=25 March 2005 |df= }}{{cite web| url=http://www.velodromes.com/list100.htm| title=CYCLE TRACKS: List of References no. 50-100}} It was the home track of [[Chris Hoy]] and [[Craig MacLean]]. Proposals published in December 2013 suggested that the velodrome be sold off for housing to fund the redevelopment of the main stadium.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/commonwealth-games/25360327 |title=Sir Chris Hoy laments loss of Meadowbank velodrome |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=12 December 2013 |accessdate=13 December 2013}} Usage of the track has declined over the years - mainly due to the construction of the [[Commonwealth Arena and Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome]], which is a track of a much better standard - but the local bicycle club, Edinburgh Road Club, still host some events on the old track.{{cite web| url=http://www.edinburghrc.co.uk/track/meadowbank-velodrome| title=Edinburgh Road Club events |date=August 2015}} ===Rugby=== Professional [[rugby union]] club [[Edinburgh Rugby|Edinburgh Gunners]] used the venue from 2002 until they moved to [[Murrayfield Stadium]] in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/scrum/rugby/story/42312.html |title=Edinburgh make Meadowbank their home |date=19 July 2002 |accessdate=28 December 2013 |work=ESPN Scrum |publisher=ESPN Sports Media}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/scrum/rugby/story/54279.html |title=Edinburgh switch home games to Murrayfield |date=22 July 2004 |accessdate=28 December 2013 |work=ESPN Scrum |publisher=ESPN Sports Media}} ===Boxing=== The Meadowbank Stadium has been used for many boxing events, Hall 1 is predominantly used and has been the location for fighters including [[Alex Arthur]], [[Ricky Burns]] etc. It was last used on 14 April 2012 when Arthur staged his self-promoted "Homecoming" fight event for the return of [[Craig McEwan (boxer)|Craig McEwan]] to Edinburgh. ===Taekwondo=== The stadium was used in November 2014 to host the [[Commonwealth Taekwondo Championships]]. ===Juggling=== Meadowbank was the venue for the [[European Juggling Convention]] in 1998. ==Redevelopment and renovation== [[File:MeadowbankEdin4.jpg|thumb|left|280px|Threatened trees outside at Edinburgh's dilapidated Meadowbank Stadium in November 2018]] In 2006 the [[City of Edinburgh Council]] published plans to demolish Meadowbank Stadium, selling the site for housing.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/6302773.stm |title=City sets sights on sports vision |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=26 January 2007 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} Meadowbank would have been replaced with a smaller community facility on the east side of the city and a stadium for athletics and rugby was to be built to the west of the city, probably in [[Sighthill, Edinburgh|Sighthill]]. The draft Meadowbank Development Brief was approved by the Council on 7 December 2006 for consultation.([http://www.edinburgh.gov.uk/internet/Environment/Planning_buildings_i_i_/Planning/Planning_policies/Development%20briefs/CEC_meadowbank_development_brief__draft_ Council's Development Brief] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070324070844/http://www.edinburgh.gov.uk/internet/Environment/Planning_buildings_i_i_/Planning/Planning_policies/Development%20briefs/CEC_meadowbank_development_brief__draft_ |date=24 March 2007 }}) The Development Brief stated that "housing is the most appropriate alternative use of the site" and that "high density development is acceptable in principle". The consultation ran until 28 March 2007, after which the council leader [[Ewan Aitken]] admitted that the Council should have consulted more with the users of Meadowbank.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/6510527.stm |title='Mistakes made' over Meadowbank |first=Mona |last=McAlinden |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=30 March 2007 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} More than 6000 people signed a petition objecting to the proposal, while 600 marched from the stadium to the City Chambers, as part of a ''Save Meadowbank'' campaign. The proposal was cast into doubt due to problems with the [[Sighthill Stadium]] project, which was scrapped in 2007.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/7336254.stm |title=Call for Meadowbank plan rethink |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=8 April 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} On 13 March 2008, Edinburgh Council voted to sell the land that is occupied by Meadowbank stadium and build a smaller sports facility on east of the site.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/pop_ups/08/uk_enl_1205249316/html/1.stm |title=New Build Options for Meadowbank |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=28 December 2013}}[http://cpol.edinburgh.gov.uk/getdoc_ext.asp?DocId=109262 National and Regional Sports facilities progress report]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[The X Factor (TV series)|X-Factor]] winner [[Leon Jackson]], who was campaigning to save Meadowbank, played at its annual [[fireworks]] display on 5 November 2008.{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment/X-Factor39s-Leon-to-perform.4629723.jp |title=X Factor's Leon to perform at firework display |publisher=Johnston Publishing |work=[[The Scotsman]] |accessdate=28 October 2008}} The proposals to sell Meadowbank were put on hold in 2009, after a decline in Edinburgh property prices. In February 2013, the City of Edinburgh Council started a new consultation process about its future.{{cite web |url=http://news.stv.tv/east-central/213232-meadowbank-stadium-under-threat-as-edinburgh-council-opens-consultation/ |title=Future of Meadowbank Stadium unclear as council opens negotiations |work=www.news.stv.tv |publisher=STV |date=8 February 2013 |accessdate=30 September 2013}} Three options for redeveloping Meadowbank were put forward for consideration by Edinburgh Council in December 2013.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-25318416 |title=Three options considered for Meadowbank Stadium in Edinburgh |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=10 December 2013 |accessdate=11 December 2013}} A planned design was made public in November 2016.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-37936286 |title=New Meadowbank Stadium design plans unveiled |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=10 November 2016 |accessdate=28 April 2017}} Work was expected to begin after the 2016–17 football season ended.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadlinenews.co.uk/2017/04/28/pitch-invasions-manchester-united-diy-emotional-edinburgh-city-prepare-meadowbank-farewell/ |title=Pitch invasions, Manchester United & DIY: Emotional Edinburgh City prepare for Meadowbank farewell |work=Deadline News |publisher= |first=Alan |last=Temple |date=28 April 2017 |accessdate=28 April 2017}} [[Edinburgh City F.C.|Edinburgh City]] reached an agreement with [[Spartans F.C.|Spartans]] to use their Ainslie Park ground for three seasons while Meadowbank was being redeveloped.{{cite news |url=http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport/football/edinburgh-city/edinburgh-city-and-spartans-confirm-three-season-groundshare-1-4407011 |title=Edinburgh City and Spartans confirm three-season groundshare |work=Edinburgh Evening News |publisher= |first=Ross |last=Pilcher |date=29 March 2017 |accessdate=28 April 2017}} A final annual fireworks display was held on 5 November 2017.{{cite web|title=Final fireworks display held at Meadowbank Stadium|url=https://stv.tv/news/east-central/1401615-final-fireworks-display-held-at-meadowbank-stadium/|website=STV News|accessdate=7 November 2017}} [[File:MeadowbankEdin1.jpg|thumb|Protest notice on tree trunk at Edinburgh's Meadowbank Stadium in November 2018]] The stadium was closed for the redevelopment works in December 2017, and the new facilities were due to reopen in the spring of 2020.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-41266208 |title=Edinburgh's Meadowbank Stadium to close in December |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=1 December 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-42182524 |title=Meadowbank to close its doors for the last time |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=1 December 2017 |accessdate=1 December 2017}} Planning applications for detailed approval for the new sports centre and in principle for development of the rest of the site were published in January 2018.https://citydev-portal.edinburgh.gov.uk/idoxpa-web/centralDistribution.do?caseType=Application&keyVal=P2LQCKEWHY800https://citydev-portal.edinburgh.gov.uk/idoxpa-web/centralDistribution.do?caseType=Application&keyVal=P2G6DJEWHU900 In July 2018, the Council approved detailed plans for the new Meadowbank Sports Centre and the redevelopment of land surrounding it for housing, student accommodation, hotel and commercial use.[https://www.scotsman.com/business/meadowbank-move-clears-its-final-hurdles-but-public-trust-has-fallen-1-4762117 Meadowbank move clears its final hurdles but public trust has fallen, Scotsman, 30 June 2018] A council consultation opened on 20 August 2018 and closed on 31 October.[https://consultationhub.edinburgh.gov.uk/sfc/meadowbank-masterplan/ Meadowbank Masterplan, City of Edinburgh] ==Community protests== Public reaction to the plan of financing a new, but downsized sports centre with the sale of land for housing and other commercial purposes has been critical.[https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/judy-murray-criticises-plans-to-downsize-sports-facilities-at-meadowbank-1-4783488 Judy Murray criticises plans to ‘downsize’ sports facilities at Meadowbank, Scotsman, 14 August 2018][https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/cycling-star-callum-skinner-mourns-loss-of-meadowbank-velodrome-1-4782759, Cycling star Callum Skinner mourns loss of Meadowbank velodrome, Edinburgh Evening News, 12 August 2018] The Meadowbank Community have produced their own rival renovation plan. [https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/entertainment/campaigners-unveil-alternative-vision-for-meadowbank-s-future-1-4799805, Campaigners unveil alternative vision for Meadowbank’s future, Edinburgh Evening News, 14 September 2018] [https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/opinion/john-mclellan-meadowbank-row-is-going-to-run-and-run-1-4809679 John McLellan: Meadowbank row is going to run and run, Edinburgh Evening News, 4 October 2018] There is also a public campaign to save the fine mature trees, including some fine examples of [[Ulmus minor 'Sarniensis'|Wheatley elm]] (Ulmus minor 'Sarniensis'), that surround the site, many of which are to be cut down in the City of Edinburgh Council redevelopment plan. [https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/campaigners-make-bid-to-save-meadowbank-trees-from-the-chop-1-4687454 Campaigners make bid to save Meadowbank trees from the chop Edinburgh Evening News, 12 February 2018] ==Gallery== File:Concert at the Meadowbank Stadium - geograph.org.uk - 1641057.jpg|Concert at the Meadowbank Stadium - geograph.org.uk - 1641057 File:Meadowbank Stadium - geograph.org.uk - 418221.jpg|Meadowbank Stadium - geograph.org.uk - 418221 File:Meadowbank Stadium - Radiohead.jpg|Meadowbank Stadium - Radiohead File:Meadowbank Stadium main stand.jpg|Meadowbank Stadium main stand File:Meadowbank Stadium stand.jpg|Meadowbank Stadium stand File:Meadowbank Stadium. - geograph.org.uk - 301834.jpg|Meadowbank Stadium. - geograph.org.uk - 301834 File:Meadowbank-5aside-215.jpg|Meadowbank-5aside-215 File:Meadowbank-basketball-215.jpg|Meadowbank-basketball-215 File:Meadowbank-track-215.jpg|Meadowbank-track-215 File:Meadowbank-track-and-field.jpg|Meadowbank-track-and-field File:Velodrome-150.jpg|Velodrome-150 File:T-on-the fringe-300.jpg|T-on-the fringe-300 File:MeadowbankEdin3.jpg|thumb|Elm trees on the street outside at Edinburgh's Meadowbank Stadium in November 2018 File:MeadowbankEdin2.jpg|thumb|Protest notices on trees at Edinburgh's Meadowbank Stadium in November 2018 ==See also== {{short description|Short documentary film}} '''''Munich '72 and Beyond''''' is a 2016 short documentary film.<ref name="Jaffee">{{cite news|title=After decades of IOC silence, slain Israeli Olympians headed for recognition|last1=Jaffee|first1=Maayan|date=22 May 2015|work=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=JNS.org}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Munich'72 and Beyond (2016)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5089526/|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref name="Zaccardi">{{cite news|title=Munich 1972 Olympic attack victims' families detail massacre in documentary|last1=Zaccardi|first1=Nick|date=1 December 2015|work=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=NBC Sports}}</ref>
The film documents the secrecy in which the ordeals undergone by the hostages has been shrouded, and follows the struggle of their surviving relatives to discover and reveal the barbarism of the attackers. In the film Ilana Romano, widow of murdered Olympic weightlifter [[Yossef Romano]], reveals that her husband was castrated. Other hostages had their bones broken by their captors.<ref name=Borden>{{cite news|last1=Borden|first1=Sam|title=Long-Hidden Details Reveal Cruelty of 1972 Munich Attackers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/02/sports/long-hidden-details-reveal-cruelty-of-1972-munich-attackers.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=second-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=1 December 2015}}</ref>
The film was produced by psychologist [[Steven Ungerleider]],<ref name=APA>{{cite news|title=Psychologist's documentary focuses on the 1972 Munich Massacre|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2015/07-08/upfront-munich.aspx|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=American Psychological Association|date=July 2015}}</ref> and [[David C. Ulich|David Ulich]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Munich'72 and Beyond (2016)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5089526/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref> Stephen Crisman was director, writer and executive producer. Michael Cascio was executive producer, and David Bret Egen was co-producer and editor.<ref>http://www.kpbs.org/news/2016/aug/12/munich-72-and-beyond/</ref> Production began in 2015<ref name=Benari>{{cite news|last1=Benari|first1=Elad|title=Documentary on 1972 Munich Massacre Begins Production|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/195103#.Vl35N3s2uUc|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Arutz 7|date=5 July 2015}}</ref> under the working title ''Munich 1972 & Beyond''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/stephen-crisman-michael-cascio-developing-777953 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |title=Stephen Crisman and Michael Cascio Developing Terrorism Documentary (Exclusive) |date=2015-02-26 |author= Bryn Elise Sandberg}}</ref> The film's runtime is 44 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-munich-olympics-memorial-elliott-20160513-column.html |title=Documentary sheds new light on killing of 11 Israelis at 1972 Munich Olympics |author=Helene Elliott |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=2016-05-12 }}</ref>
== Awards ==
=== 2017 === * 38th Annual News & Documentary Awards: Nominated in the Outstanding Research category<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://emmyonline.com/news_38th_nominations|title=NOMINEES FOR THE 38th ANNUAL NEWS & DOCUMENTARY EMMY® AWARDS ANNOUNCED {{!}} The Emmy Awards - The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences|website=emmyonline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> * 2017 Euro Shorts Fest: Best Documentary <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.euroshortsfest.com/euro/content.asp|title=Euro Shorts Fest|website=www.euroshortsfest.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
=== 2016 === * LA Shorts Fest: Best Documentary <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aroundtherings.com/site/A__57442/Title__Munich-72-and-Beyond-Wins-Best-Documentary-at-LA-Shorts-Fest/292/Articles|title=Munich '72 and Beyond Wins Best Documentary at LA Shorts Fest|website=aroundtherings.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{official|http://sidewinderfilms.org/munich-72-and-beyond/}} * {{imdb title|5089526}} * [http://pbsinternational.org/programs/munich-72-and-beyond/ ''Munich '72 and Beyond'' at PBS International] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7CKN45BzYU Munich Memorial Project Interview with Dr. Steven Ungerleider]
